column4: Scenario: One ubuntu server (moderately weak CPU) behind router. A second client running Windows attempting to access the network from a different location. Requirements: Client does not know Linux, wants to connect to a windows system. OK, so what are the best ways to get the Job done. I was thinking Xen+Installing XP on the Ubuntu machine. Is that a good idea ?
uhm
what *exactly* are you trying to do?
oh ok
seems a slightly convoluted way to do things
well I don't really know what you're trying to do
does the user need a particular Windows-only application, or something?
user is unfamiliar with linux, and will take too long to familiarize with + yes probably needs MS word
give them an XP desktop then
or just give them and Ubuntu desktop and let them get on with it
there is no practical difference for normal users
how can i give them an XP desktop from a remote location ?
I don't understand your question
why are they connecting to a remote machine at all?
you haven't really given a clear statement of the problem
as I understand it, you have a server that you want to run a bunch of XP virtual machines on, and connect to them remotely from some other machine, is that right?
ok, why specifically do you want virtual machines running on the server?
incidentally qemu will allow you to do something like that with XP apparently
it's possible, it's not even particularly hard to do, but I have a sneaky feeling you're trying to solve the wrong problem
why do you want lots of virtual machines on one server?  What is the user running locally?
I *think* you're looking for qemu and seamless desktop
I don't want to run specific windows applications on linux. I want the user to be completely oblivious to the fact that a linux machine even exists
in any case, the chances of anyone getting your password even if it is sent in cleartext is fairly remote
